title: Netflix offers employees unlimited parental leave
text:

Wed, Aug 5, 2015, 10:26 BST - UK Markets close in 6 hrs 4 mins Netflix offers employees unlimited parental leave By Sophie Jamieson | Telegraph – 1 minute 15 seconds ago 113.149 +5.849 
Online film and TV streaming service Netflix (Xetra: 552484 - news ) will now let parents take as much maternity and paternity leave as they want for up to a year 
Mums and dads working for Netflix (Hanover: NFC.HA - news ) in the USA will now get “unlimited” parental leave for the first year of their child’s life, the company has announced. 
In a blog post , Tawni Cranz, Netflix’s chief talent officer, said the policy was designed to give employees “the flexibility and confidence to balance the needs of their growing families without worrying about work or finances”. 
The offer applies to both maternity and paternity leave in the first year after either birth or adoption. The employees will still be paid their full salary in that time. 
Parents will be allowed to return part-time, full-time or temporarily. 
The employee benefit is particularly generous for the US, where women are only entitled to 12 weeks of unpaid leave. 
Shows like Orange (Taiwan OTC: 4554.TWO - news ) is the New Black have been hits for Netflix online (Netflix) 
Netflix, which has produced hit shows House of Cards and Orange is the New Black , said the policy fitted with the company’s “freedom and responsibility culture” and would help attract and retain the best talent in Silicon Valley. 
“Each employee gets to figure out what’s best for them and their family, and then works with their managers for coverage during their absences,” Ms Cranz said. 
People tend to “perform better at work when they’re not worrying about home”, she added, saying employees would “return to work more focused and dedicated” as a result. 
The move follows the decision by Netflix and other companies like Virgin to let workers take as much holiday as they want. 
But the seemingly generous offers have been criticised by some. 
Virgin allows staff to take as much time off as they want - provided they “feel a hundred per cent comfortable that they and their team are up to date on every project and that their absence will not in any way damage the business”, which some argue could make employees actually take less time off.
